elements.content: Reaction in aqueous solution of cadmium nitrate, succinic acid (H2suc), and one of four possible isomeric dipyridylamide coligands has afforded a series of two-dimensional (2-D) and three-dimensional (3-D) coordination polymers. All were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. [Cd(suc)(4-pina)] n (1, 4-pina = 4-pyridylisonicotinamide) displays a 3-D 6-connected self-penetrated 446108 mab topology, while {[Cd(suc)(3-pna)]·2.5H2O} n (2, 3-pna = 3-pyridylnicotinamide) has a simple 3-D non-interpenetrated 41263 pcu network. The supramolecular isomer 2′ has exactly the same stoichiometry and overall pcu topology as 2 but shows a difference in succinate binding mode. Compounds 1, 2, and 2′ all show similar [Cd(suc)] n layers with embedded {Cd2O2} rhomboid dimers that serve as the 6-connected nodes. {[Cd(suc)(4-pna)(H2O)]·2H2O} n (3, 4-pna = 4-pyridylnicotinamide) manifests an extremely rare 2-D 4-connected 66 layer self-penetrated topology based on cross-pillared [Cd(suc)] n helical chains. Slight adjustment of the donor disposition resulted in the formation of the 2-D (4,4) grid coordination polymer {[Cd(suc)(3-pina)(H2O)]·3.5H2O} n (4, 3-pina = 3-pyridylisonicotinamide), which has [Cd(suc)] n helical chains similar to those in 3 but avoids cross-pillaring. Luminescent and thermal properties of these four new materials are discussed.

Compounds 1, 2, and 2' all show similar [Cd(suc)] n  layers with embedded {Cd2O2} rhomboid dimers that serve as the 6-connected nodes. {[Cd(suc)(4-pna)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (3, 4-pna = 4-pyridylnicotinamide) manifests an extremely rare 2-D 4-connected 66 layer self-penetrated topology based on cross-pillared [Cd(suc)] n  helical chains. Luminescent and thermal properties of these four new materials are discussed.

elements.content: Cadmium succinate coordination polymers with one of four isomeric dipyridylamides show significant structure direction by the nitrogen coligand, from rare self-penetrated 3-D nets and 2-D layers to more common 3-D cubic and 2-D grid topologies.
elements.clean_text: Cadmium succinate coordination polymers with one of four isomeric dipyridylamides show significant structure direction by the nitrogen coligand, from rare self-penetrated 3-D nets and 2-D layers to more common 3-D cubic and 2-D grid topologies.

elements.content: Research into the design, synthesis, and structural characterization of crystalline coordination polymers has continued apace over the past decade. These materials’ often striking structural aesthetics and diverse multifunctional applications in hydrogen storage, selective molecular separations, ion exchange, heterogeneous catalysis, and nonlinear optics provide the impetus for continued investigations. Although aromatic dicarboxylates have been the most commonly used anionic linkers because of their structural rigidity, there has been an increasing trend toward the synthesis of coordination polymers containing conformationally flexible aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands. Because of facile σ-bond rotation during self-assembly, the central polymethylene tethers of the aliphatic dicarboxylate chains have the ability to respond to specific supramolecular environments dictated by metal coordination geometry preference or the presence of neutral dipyridyl-type coligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Research into the design, synthesis, and structural characterization of crystalline coordination polymers has continued apace over the past decade. These materials' often striking structural aesthetics and diverse multifunctional applications in hydrogen storage, selective molecular separations, ion exchange, heterogeneous catalysis, and nonlinear optics provide the impetus for continued investigations. Although aromatic dicarboxylates have been the most commonly used anionic linkers because of their structural rigidity, there has been an increasing trend toward the synthesis of coordination polymers containing conformationally flexible aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands. Because of facile σ-bond rotation during self-assembly, the central polymethylene tethers of the aliphatic dicarboxylate chains have the ability to respond to specific supramolecular environments dictated by metal coordination geometry preference or the presence of neutral dipyridyl-type coligands.

elements.content: The straight-chain aliphatic dicarboxylates succinate (suc), glutarate (glu), and adipate (adp) have afforded a variety of dual-ligand coordination polymer topologies, including some rather uncommon self-penetrated networks in which shortest circuits pass through other shortest circuits in the network. For example, {[Cd(suc)(bispyridin-4-yl-methylsuccinamide)]·H2O} n manifests cadmium/dipyridyl triple helices linked into a vanishingly rare 2-D 4-connected self-penetrated layer net by gauche conformation suc ligands. {[Ni(suc)0.5(dpa)2]Cl} n (dpa = 4,4′-dipyridylamine) is the unique example of regular 5-connected self-penetrated 3-D net (6 rld-z topology), while its cadmium analogue {[Cd(suc)(dpa)]·H2O} n has a 2-fold interpenetrated pcu net based on {Cd2O2} dimeric units. A self-penetrated 6-connected 48668 rob lattice is observed in the 3-D coordination polymer {[Cu2(glu)2(bpy)]·3H2O} n (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine).

For example, {[Cd(suc)(bispyridin-4-yl-methylsuccinamide)]⋅H2O} n  manifests cadmium/dipyridyl triple helices linked into a vanishingly rare 2-D 4-connected self-penetrated layer net by gauche conformation suc ligands. {[Ni(suc)0.5(dpa)2]Cl} n  (dpa = 4,4'-dipyridylamine) is the unique example of regular 5-connected self-penetrated 3-D net (6 rld-z topology), while its cadmium analogue {[Cd(suc)(dpa)]⋅H2O} n  has a 2-fold interpenetrated pcu net based on {Cd2O2} dimeric units. A self-penetrated 6-connected 48668 rob lattice is observed in the 3-D coordination polymer {[Cu2(glu)2(bpy)]⋅3H2O} n  (bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine).

elements.content: The isomeric dipyridylamides 3-pyridylnicotinamide (3-pna), 3-pyridylisonicotinamide (3-pina), 4-pyridylnicotinamide (4-pna), and 4-pyridylisonicotinamide (4-pina) (Scheme ) are easily prepared from the requisite pyridylamine and acid chloride in pyridine. Despite their facile synthesis, their use as linkers in divalent metal dicarboxylate coordination polymer chemistry remains rather underunexplored. These four dipyridylamides have a similar internal arrangement of hydrogen bonding donor and acceptor groups, thus removing some of the hard to predict supramolecular effects as a variable in terms of structure direction. Employing the different dipyridylamides while keeping the metal and dicarboxylate components the same could reveal the structure directing effects of nitrogen donor disposition across a series of related coordination polymers. Zinc succinate coordination polymers containing 4-pna and 4-pina have recently been reported; [Zn(suc)(4-pna)] n has a simple corrugated (4,4) grid structure, while [Zn(suc)(4-pina)] n displays an uncommon 6-connected self-penetrated 446108 mab topology. Thus, it appears that employing different dipyridylamides in the synthetic scheme is a successful tactic toward instilling structural diversity in a specific metal dicarboxylate system.

Thus, it appears that employing different dipyridylamides in the synthetic scheme is a successful tactic toward instilling structural diversity in a specific metal dicarboxylate system.

elements.content: We therefore aimed to extend these preliminary zinc succinate results into a full series of cadmium succinate coordination polymers containing one of the four isomeric dipyridylamides. Our efforts resulted in the successful preparation of four new cadmium succinate coordination polymers: [Cd(suc)(4-pina)] n (1), {[Cd(suc)(3-pna)]·2.5H2O} n (2), {[Cd(suc)(4-pna)(H2O)]·2H2O} n (3), and {[Cd(suc)(3-pina)(H2O)]·3.5H2O} n (4). A supramolecular isomer of 2, 2′, was also isolated. Their single-crystal X-ray structures, luminescent properties, and thermal degradation behavior are discussed herein.

A supramolecular isomer of 2, 2', was also isolated. Their single-crystal X-ray structures, luminescent properties, and thermal degradation behavior are discussed herein.

elements.content: Cadmium nitrate and succinic acid were purchased commercially. The ligands 3-pna, 3-pina, 4-pna, and 4-pina were prepared by a published procedure. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed under flowing N2 on a TA Instruments TGA 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 450 °C. Luminescence spectra were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive. Maximum excitation wavelengths were determined by monitoring emission at 400 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

Cadmium nitrate and succinic acid were purchased commercially. The ligands 3-pna, 3-pina, 4-pna, and 4-pina were prepared by a published procedure. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed under flowing N2 on a TA Instruments TGA 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 450 °C. Luminescence spectra were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive. Maximum excitation wavelengths were determined by monitoring emission at 400 nm.

elements.content: Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (28 mg, 0.09 mmol) and succinic acid (14 mg, 0.11 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of H2O in a 15 mL glass vial. A 4 mL aliquot of a 1:1 ethanol/water solution was pipetted on top, followed by 3 mL of an ethanolic solution of 4-pina (18 mg, 0.09 mmol). The vial was allowed to stand uncapped for two weeks, whereupon colorless crystals were deposited.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Cd(suc)(4-pina)] n  (1)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (28 mg, 0.09 mmol) and succinic acid (14 mg, 0.11 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of H2O in a 15 mL glass vial. A 4 mL aliquot of a 1:1 ethanol/water solution was pipetted on top, followed by 3 mL of an ethanolic solution of 4-pina (18 mg, 0.09 mmol). The vial was allowed to stand uncapped for two weeks, whereupon colorless crystals were deposited.

elements.content: Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (57 mg, 0.185 mmol), succinic acid (50 mg, 0.185 mmol), and 3-pna (37 mg, 0.185 mmol) were placed into 5 mL of distilled H2O in a 15 mL screw-cap vial, along with 1 mL of a 1.0 M NaOH solution. The vial was sealed and heated in an oil bath at 70 °C for 48 h and then cooled slowly to 25 °C. Colorless crystals of 2 and 2′ (14 mg, 16% yield based on Cd) were isolated after washing with distilled water and acetone, and drying in air. Compound 2 crystallized as blocks, while compound 2′ crystallized as needles. The different morphology allowed for distinction of the major product 2 and the minor product 2′. Bulk manual separation proved too difficult. Anal. Calc. for C60H72Cd4N12O30 4: C, 38.11; H, 3.84; N, 8.89% Found: C, 38.66; H, 3.42; N, 8.76%. IR (cm–1): 3207 (w, br), 1684 (m), 1584 (m), 1552 (s), 1479 (w), 1432 (m), 1418 (m), 1393 (s), 1327 (w), 1282 (s), 1180 (w), 1133 (w), 1051 (m), 1032 (m), 963 (w), 884 (s), 859 (w), 827 (w), 802 (s), 692 (s).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction on crystals of 1–4 was performed using a Bruker-AXS ApexII CCD instrument at 173 K. Reflection data were acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the amide nitrogen atoms and water molecule oxygen atoms (where possible) were found by Fourier difference map and refined with restrained distances and isotropic thermal parameters. The crystal of 1 was nonmerohedrally twinned; its twin law was found using CELLNOW. Attempts were made to solve and refine the structure of 1 in the centrosymmetric space group P21 /c; these proved unsatisfactory relative to the solution and refinement in the acentric space group Pc. The Flack parameter of 0.09(12) indicates the likelihood of the acentric space group, perhaps with a small amount of racemic twinning. Relevant crystallographic data for 1–4 are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction on crystals of 1-4 was performed using a Bruker-AXS ApexII CCD instrument at 173 K. Reflection data were acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the amide nitrogen atoms and water molecule oxygen atoms (where possible) were found by Fourier difference map and refined with restrained distances and isotropic thermal parameters. The crystal of 1 was nonmerohedrally twinned; its twin law was found using CELLNOW. Attempts were made to solve and refine the structure of 1 in the centrosymmetric space group P21 /c; these proved unsatisfactory relative to the solution and refinement in the acentric space group Pc. The Flack parameter of 0.09(12) indicates the likelihood of the acentric space group, perhaps with a small amount of racemic twinning. Relevant crystallographic data for 1-4 are listed in Table .

Compounds 1 and 3 were prepared as crystalline products by the slow diffusion an aqueous solution of cadmium nitrate and succinic acid and an ethanol solution of either 4-pina or 4-pna, respectively. This method of synthesis was necessitated by the failure of hydrothermal techniques in these cases. When the synthesis of 1 was attempted via hydrothermal methods, only the known molecular complex [Cd(isonicotinate)2(H2O)4] was formed, via hydrolysis of the 4-pina precursor. No single crystalline products could be obtained during hydrothermal synthetic attempts for compound 3. Compounds 2/2′ and 4 were prepared by hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate, succinic acid, and either 3-pna or 3-pina, respectively. Their infrared spectra were consistent with structural components determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Intense, slightly broadened asymmetric and symmetric carboxylate C–O stretching bands for the dicarboxylate ligands were observed at 1543 and 1408 cm–1 for 1, 1552 and 1393 cm–1 for 2/2′, 1553 and 1427 cm–1 for 3, and 1537 and 1429 cm–1 for 4. Sharp and medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600 cm–1 to ∼1300 cm–1 were attributed to stretching mode of the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamide ligands in 1–4. Broad weak spectral bands in the vicinity of ∼3000 cm–1 to ∼3500 cm–1 indicate the presence of N–H bonds within the pyridylamide ligands in 1–4, unbound water molecules in 1. The CO stretching band of the carbonyl groups of the dipyridylamide ligands in 1–4 are visible in the vicinity of ∼1670 cm–1 to ∼1700 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Spectral Characterization

Compounds 1 and 3 were prepared as crystalline products by the slow diffusion an aqueous solution of cadmium nitrate and succinic acid and an ethanol solution of either 4-pina or 4-pna, respectively. This method of synthesis was necessitated by the failure of hydrothermal techniques in these cases. When the synthesis of 1 was attempted via hydrothermal methods, only the known molecular complex [Cd(isonicotinate)2(H2O)4] was formed, via hydrolysis of the 4-pina precursor. No single crystalline products could be obtained during hydrothermal synthetic attempts for compound 3. Compounds 2/2' and 4 were prepared by hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate, succinic acid, and either 3-pna or 3-pina, respectively. Their infrared spectra were consistent with structural components determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Intense, slightly broadened asymmetric and symmetric carboxylate C-O stretching bands for the dicarboxylate ligands were observed at 1543 and 1408 cm-1 for 1, 1552 and 1393 cm-1 for 2/2', 1553 and 1427 cm-1 for 3, and 1537 and 1429 cm-1 for 4. Sharp and medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600 cm-1 to ~1300 cm-1 were attributed to stretching mode of the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamide ligands in 1-4. Broad weak spectral bands in the vicinity of ~3000 cm-1 to ~3500 cm-1 indicate the presence of N-H bonds within the pyridylamide ligands in 1-4, unbound water molecules in 1. The CO stretching band of the carbonyl groups of the dipyridylamide ligands in 1-4 are visible in the vicinity of ~1670 cm-1 to ~1700 cm-1.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the acentric space group Pc with a Flack parameter of 0.09(12) indicating a large degree of enantiomeric purity within the crystal. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two divalent Cd atoms, two suc ligands (suc-A, suc-B), and two 4-pina ligands. Both cadmium atoms possess a distorted {CdN2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment, with 4-pina pyridyl nitrogen donors in the axial position. The equatorial plane of each coordination sphere contains a chelating carboxylate group from suc-A, a chelating carboxylate group from suc-B, and an additional single oxygen donor from a carboxylate group of a second suc-B ligand. Bond lengths and angles about the cadmium atoms are listed in Table . The coordination environments are depicted in Figure .

The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two divalent Cd atoms, two suc ligands (suc-A, suc-B), and two 4-pina ligands. Both cadmium atoms possess a distorted {CdN2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment, with 4-pina pyridyl nitrogen donors in the axial position. The equatorial plane of each coordination sphere contains a chelating carboxylate group from suc-A, a chelating carboxylate group from suc-B, and an additional single oxygen donor from a carboxylate group of a second suc-B ligand. Bis(chelating) suc-A ligands with a μ2-κ4O,O′:O″,O‴ binding mode and exotetradentate suc-B ligands with a μ4-κ4O,O′:O′:O″,O‴:O‴ binding mode (Scheme ) connect cadmium ions into [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n coordination polymer layer motifs that lie parallel to the ac crystal planes (Figure ). Embedded within the layers are {Cd2O2} rhomboid units formed via single oxygen atom donors from two suc-B ligands; these have Cd···Cd and O···O distances of 3.783 and 3.094 Å, respectively. The rhombuses are slightly pinched, with Cd···O···Cd and O···Cd···O angles of 97.91° and 79.31°. If the centroids of the {Cd2O2} rhomboid dimers are treated as connecting nodes, the [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n layers can be considered to be standard (4,4) grids.

Embedded within the layers are {Cd2O2} rhomboid units formed via single oxygen atom donors from two suc-B ligands; these have Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd and O⋅⋅⋅O distances of 3.783 and 3.094 Å, respectively. The rhombuses are slightly pinched, with Cd⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅Cd and O⋅⋅⋅Cd⋅⋅⋅O angles of 97.91° and 79.31°. If the centroids of the {Cd2O2} rhomboid dimers are treated as connecting nodes, the [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n  layers can be considered to be standard (4,4) grids.

elements.clean_text: 2  [Cd(suc)] n  layer subunit in 1, revealing the {Cd2O2} dimers.

elements.content: Both the suc-A and suc-B ligands display a distorted anti conformation with subtly different four C-atom torsion angles, at 169.6 and 162.1°, respectively. The closest Cd···Cd contact distance through the bis(chelating) suc-A ligands is 8.875 Å; the related distance across the strictly chelating donors of the suc-B ligands is 9.473 Å. These distances loosely define the perimeters of the (4,4) grids within the [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n layers.
elements.clean_text: Both the suc-A and suc-B ligands display a distorted anti conformation with subtly different four C-atom torsion angles, at 169.6 and 162.1°, respectively. The closest Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd contact distance through the bis(chelating) suc-A ligands is 8.875 Å; the related distance across the strictly chelating donors of the suc-B ligands is 9.473 Å. These distances loosely define the perimeters of the (4,4) grids within the [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n  layers.

elements.content: Parallel, flat [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n layers are connected into a 3-D [Cd(suc)(4-pina)] n network by pairs of 4-pina ligands that bridge {Cd2O2} rhomboid dimers with an interlayer Cd···Cd distance of 13.917 Å. Notably the closest through-space interlayer Cd···Cd distance is 9.283 Å (b lattice parameter), too short for the 4-pina ligands to bridge. As a result, the 4-pina ligands cross each other in the region between the adjacent [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n layers (Figure a). Treating the {Cd2O2} dimeric units as 6-connected nodes and pairs of 4-pina ligands as single linkers reveals the presence of an underlying self-penetrated mab net with 446108 topology (Figure b). Hydrogen bonding () between the 4-pina amine groups and the ligated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the bis(chelating) suc-A ligands possibly serves an ancillary structure-directing role in self-assembly of the self-penetrated network of 1.

As a result, the 4-pina ligands cross each other in the region between the adjacent [Cd2(suc-A)(suc-B)] n  layers (Figure a). Treating the {Cd2O2} dimeric units as 6-connected nodes and pairs of 4-pina ligands as single linkers reveals the presence of an underlying self-penetrated mab net with 446108 topology (Figure b). Hydrogen bonding () between the 4-pina amine groups and the ligated carboxylate oxygen atoms of the bis(chelating) suc-A ligands possibly serves an ancillary structure-directing role in self-assembly of the self-penetrated network of 1.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the primitive monoclinic space group P21/c with a large asymmetric unit containing four divalent cadmium atoms, four suc ligands (suc-A, suc-B, suc-C, suc-D), four 3-pna ligands, and a total of 10 water molecules of crystallization. Cadmium atoms Cd1 and Cd3 display a distorted {CdN2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment as in 1, with axial 3-pna pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms and equatorial sites containing two chelating carboxylate groups from different suc ligands and a single oxygen atom donor from another suc ligand (Figure a). The chelating carboxylate groups at Cd1 belong to suc-A and suc-B ligands, while those at Cd3 belong to suc-B and suc-C. The single oxygen donor at Cd1 is part of a second suc-C ligand, while that at Cd3 is part of a second suc-B ligand. Dissimilar to 1, cadmium atoms Cd2 and Cd4 have a distorted octahedral {CdN2O4} coordination geometry (Figure b). In both of these cases, the axial positions are taken up by 3-pna pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms, while the equatorial planes consist of a chelating suc carboxylate group and cis single oxygen donor atoms from two different suc ligands. At Cd2, the chelating carboxylate group is supplied by a suc-D ligand, while the single donors are provided by suc-A and suc-C ligands. A suc-A chelating carboxylate group and single donors from two suc-D ligands round out the coordination environment at Cd4. Bond lengths and angles within the diverse coordination environments in 2 are listed in Table .

As opposed to the bridging and exotetradentate binding modes seen in 1, the suc ligands in 2 all bridge three cadmium atoms, albeit with some subtle differences in binding mode (Scheme ). The suc-A and suc-B ligands have an exotridentate μ3-κ4O,O′:O″,O‴:O‴ binding mode, while the suc-C and suc-D ligands possess an exotridentate μ3-κ3O,O′:O″:O″ binding mode where one carboxylate group remains unligated. These unligated oxygen atoms do show some weak electronic interactions with nearby cadmium atoms (2.751 Å and 2.893 Å). The various bridging and binding modes of the suc ligands create [Cd(suc)] n layer motifs aligned along the ab crystal planes, with embedded {Cd2O2} dimeric units formed by the bridging single oxygen atom donors from suc carboxylate groups (Figure ). There are three crystallographically distinct rhomboid dimeric units. Cd1 and Cd2 are joined by bridging oxygen atoms provided by suc-A and suc-C ligands, a pair of Cd3 atoms is joined by bridging oxygen atoms belonging to two suc-B ligands, and a pair of Cd4 atoms is bridged by single oxygen atoms that are part of two suc-D ligands. The Cd···Cd and O···O through-space distances across these respective sets of dimers measure 3.743 and 2.784 Å, 3.752 and 2.810 Å, and 3.726 and 2.783 Å. As in 1, if the {Cd2O2} rhomboid dimers are treated as connecting nodes, the [Cd(suc)] n layer motifs can be rendered as simple (4,4) grids.

elements.content: In contrast to the anti conformation of the suc ligands in 1, those in 2 rest in a gauche conformation. The respective four C-atom torsion angles for suc-A, suc-B, suc-C, and suc-D are 71.6, 69.4, 62.2, and 65.1°. Because of the gauche conformation of the suc ligands, the [Cd(suc)] n layers in 2 adopt a zigzag perspective when viewed from the side, unlike the flatter aspect of the related layers in 1. Rhomboid dimers in adjacent [Cd(suc)] n layers are pillared by cis-conformation 3-pna ligands into a 3-D [Cd(suc)(3-pna)] n coordination polymer network (Figure a). An isolated perspective of the linkage of {Cd2O2} rhomboid units by 3-pna ligands is shown in Figure b, revealing supporting π–π stacking interactions between neighboring 3-pna pyridyl rings (centroid-to-centroid distances from 3.619(2) to 3.779(2) Å). The Cd···Cd through-ligand distances across the 3-pna tethers range between 10.94 and 10.98 Å, approximately 3 Å shorter than the related distance through the 4-pina ligands in 1.

elements.content: Treating the dimers as 6-connected nodes reveals a simple non-interpenetrated 41263 pcu topology in 2 (Figure c), in contrast to the 6-connected self-penetrated mab net seen in 1. Because of the shorter distance between pyridyl nitrogen donors in cis conformation 3-pna ligands, and the sawtooth rippling of the [Cd(suc)] n layers in 2, the need for cross-pillaring and a self-penetrated network is obviated. Within solvent-accessible incipient voids in 2 totaling 12.5% of the unit cell volume (as determined by PLATON) are situated D(4)A(1) classification water molecule pentamers, with an arrangement reminiscent of 2-methylbutane. These are anchored to the coordination polymer framework by hydrogen-bonding mechanisms involving the suc carboxylate groups and the 3-pna central amide regions (). In contrast to the straight-pillaring of the 3-pna ligand pairs in 2, the cross-pillaring of the 4-pina ligand pairs within the interlayer regions in 1 prevents any solvent-accessible void space in the latter case.

All of the suc ligands in 2′ adopt an exotridentate μ3-κ4O,O′:O″,O‴:O‴ binding mode (Scheme ), seen in only half of the suc ligands in 2. The suc ligands in 2′ remain in a gauche conformation with a four C-atom torsion angle of 66.4°. Thus, the only difference between 2 and 2′ is that there are no unligated suc carboxylate atoms in 2′. As a result 2 and 2′ can be considered true supramolecular isomers. The exotridentate suc ligands in 2′ form [Cd(suc)] n layers with embedded {Cd2O2} dimers (Figure ), which have Cd···Cd and O···O through-space distances of 3.737 and 2.772 Å respectively. These layers are pillared by cis-conformation 3-pna ligands spanning a Cd···Cd distance of 10.954 Å generate a 3-D [Cd(suc)(3-pna)] n coordination polymer network in 2′, virtually identical to that of its supramolecular isomer 2. The same pcu topology is observed in 2′, again treating the {Cd2O2} dimers as 6-connected nodes.

Compound 3 crystallized in the acentric monoclinic space group C2; enantiomeric purity within the crystal is averred by the Flack parameter of −0.033(14). Its asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent cadmium atoms, two suc ligands, two 4-pna ligands, two ligated water molecules, and four water molecules of crystallization. Both Cd atoms display a very similar {CdO5N2} pentagonal bipyramidal coordination sphere whose axial positions are occupied by an aqua ligand and a 4-pyridylamine nitrogen donor from a 4-pna ligand (Figure a). In the equatorial plane are chelating carboxylate groups from two different suc ligands and a nicotinamide pyridyl nitrogen donor. In contrast to the trans dispositions of the pyridyl nitrogen donors in 1, 2, and 2′, those in 3 are oriented in a cis manner. Bond lengths and angles about the metal centers in 3 are given in Table .

All of suc ligands in 3 adopt a simple bis(chelating) μ2-κ4O,O′:O″,O‴ binding mode (Scheme ), bridging cadmium atoms into [Cd(suc)] n chains that are arranged parallel to the b crystal direction. Because of the lack of any exotridentate or exotetradentate suc ligands, formation of [Cd(suc)] n layers like those observed in 1, 2, and 2′ is not possible. The Cd···Cd distances through the gauche conformation (torsion angle = 54.1°) suc ligands is 6.137 or 6.161 Å. Parallel [Cd(suc)] n chains are cross-pillared by 4-pna ligands to construct [Cd(suc)(4-pna)(H2O)] n layer motifs (Figure b) that possess an extremely rare 4-connected 66 self-penetrated network topology. Between neighboring [Cd(suc)] n chains within the [Cd(suc)(4-pna)(H2O)] n layers, the closest Cd···Cd contact distances measure 8.483 and 8.515 Å. This distance is too short to be spanned by the 4-pna dipodal tethers, creating the need for cross-pillaring (Figure c). The Cd···Cd internuclear distances through the dipyridylamide ligands are 12.524 and 12.545 Å. Hydrogen bonding donation from the 4-pna amide moieties to suc carboxylate oxygen atoms provides ancillary structural stabilization for the self-penetrated layer topology in 3.

elements.content: This particular 2-D self-penetrated topology observed in 3 has only been seen previously in {[Ni(oxybisbenzoate)(dpa)]·H2O} n and [Cd2(4-methylphthalate)2(dpp)3] n (dpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane). The self-penetrated layer can also be viewed as the linkage through suc ligands of adjacent, parallel [Cd(4-pna)] n 2n+ cationic double helices. Isolated water molecule pairs lie in the regions between parallel [Cd(suc)(4-pna)(H2O)] n layers (), held in place by hydrogen bonding donation to suc carboxylate oxygen atoms and 4-pna carbonyl groups. These water molecules occupy a solvent-accessible void space comprising 9.4% of the unit cell volume.

As in 3, bis(chelating) suc ligands in a gauche conformation (torsion angle = 63.88°) with a μ2-κ4O,O′:O″,O‴ binding mode connect cadmium atoms into undulating [Cd(suc)] n chains with a Cd···Cd contact distance of 6.945 Å. These chains are oriented parallel to the [1 0 1] crystal direction and are pillared by 3-pina ligands into 2-D [Cd(suc)(3-pina)(H2O)] n coordination polymer layers (Figure b). The closest Cd···Cd distance between [Cd(suc)] n chains within a single [Cd(suc)(3-pina)(H2O)] n layer is 11.910 Å, able to be bridged by the 3-pina ligands. Thus, in contrast to the rare 4-connected self-penetrated layer topology of 3, that of 4 is a simple (4,4) 4-connected regular grid. The gauche conformation of the suc ligands allows half of the axial sites of neighboring cadmium coordination spheres to tilt toward each other, permitting π–π stacking between the pyridyl rings of the 3-pna ligands (centroid-to-centroid distance = 3.474(2) Å).

elements.content: Adjacent [Cd(suc)(3-pina)(H2O)] n coordination polymer layers stack in an AAA pattern along the a crystal direction (), forming incipient channels occupying 19.1% of the unit cell volume, filled with cocrystallized water molecules. Trimers of fully occupied water molecules within these channels link through symmetry disordered water molecules to form discrete water molecule chains of varying lengths. These are anchored to the coordination polymer backbone by hydrogen-bonding donation to suc carboxylate oxygen atoms, and by hydrogen-bonding acceptance from the 3-pina amide moieties ().

elements.content: Powdered solid samples of 1–4 were irradiated with ultraviolet light in order to investigate their photoluminescent properties. All showed broad emission profiles with emission maxima occurring in the ultraviolet or violet regions, and tails into the blue-violet region (Figure ). The structurally related 3-D coordination polymers 1 and 2/2′ (6-connected self-penetrated mab and nonself-penetrated pcu topologies, respectively) showed very similar emission maxima (415 and 413 nm, respectively). The dipyridyl ligand pairs show similar π–π stacking interactions, despite the difference in overall 6-connected topology. Thus, the local environments are largely similar, perhaps resulting in similar luminescent properties. The free 4-pina and 3-pna ligands show emission maxima at 405 and 415 nm, respectively. The 2-D coordination polymers 3 and 4 (self-penetrated 66 and standard (4,4) grid topologies, respectively) showed a wider disparity in emission maxima, with that of 4 (434 nm) rather red-shifted from that of 3 (382 nm). A similar significant red shift is seen for the free 3-pina ligand (emission maximum 462 nm) versus the free 4-pna ligand (emission maximum 407 nm). As the dicarboxylate ligands in 1–4 are nonemissive, all photoluminescent behavior must be attributed to π–π* or π–n transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of the dipyridylamide ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

Powdered solid samples of 1-4 were irradiated with ultraviolet light in order to investigate their photoluminescent properties. All showed broad emission profiles with emission maxima occurring in the ultraviolet or violet regions, and tails into the blue-violet region (Figure ). The structurally related 3-D coordination polymers 1 and 2/2' (6-connected self-penetrated mab and nonself-penetrated pcu topologies, respectively) showed very similar emission maxima (415 and 413 nm, respectively). The dipyridyl ligand pairs show similar π-π stacking interactions, despite the difference in overall 6-connected topology. Thus, the local environments are largely similar, perhaps resulting in similar luminescent properties. The free 4-pina and 3-pna ligands show emission maxima at 405 and 415 nm, respectively. The 2-D coordination polymers 3 and 4 (self-penetrated 66 and standard (4,4) grid topologies, respectively) showed a wider disparity in emission maxima, with that of 4 (434 nm) rather red-shifted from that of 3 (382 nm). A similar significant red shift is seen for the free 3-pina ligand (emission maximum 462 nm) versus the free 4-pna ligand (emission maximum 407 nm). As the dicarboxylate ligands in 1-4 are nonemissive, all photoluminescent behavior must be attributed to π-π* or π-n transitions within the molecular orbital manifolds of the dipyridylamide ligands.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on compounds 1–4 to investigate their degradation behavior. Compound 1 exhibited no mass loss until 185 °C, at which point ligand combustion occurred. Its mass remnant of 36.7% at 450 °C is roughly consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (40.1% calc’d). Compound 2/2′ likely partially dehydrated upon standing at room temperature upon storage for over a month, with a 2.0% mass loss between 40 and 80 °C indicative of removal of the remaining cocrystallized water molecules. The expected mass percent of cocrystallized water for the as-synthesized sample was 9.5%. Ligand ejection for 2/2′ occurred at ∼200 °C. The final mass remnant of 41.5% at 450 °C was consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (39.4% calc’d assuming loss of 2 equiv of water). Compound 3 showed a mass loss of 11.2% between ∼65 °C and ∼150 °C, matching exactly that predicted for removal of all aqua ligands and cocrystallized water molecules. Ligand combustion was evident from a rapid mass loss at ∼270 °C. Its mass remnant of 38.3% at 450 °C is consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (35.7% calc’d) along with some uncombusted organics. Compound 4 exhibited a mass loss of 15.2% between 60 and 100 °C, matching well with the removal of all aqua ligands and cocrystallized water molecules (15.9% calc’d). Ligand ejection occurred above 270 °C. The final mass remnant of 35.8% is consistent with a likely deposition of CdCO3 (33.8% calc’d) and a small amount of uncombusted organics. Thermograms for 1–4 are shown in , respectively.

Its mass remnant of 36.7% at 450 °C is roughly consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (40.1% calc'd). Compound 2/2' likely partially dehydrated upon standing at room temperature upon storage for over a month, with a 2.0% mass loss between 40 and 80 °C indicative of removal of the remaining cocrystallized water molecules. The expected mass percent of cocrystallized water for the as-synthesized sample was 9.5%. Ligand ejection for 2/2' occurred at ~200 °C. The final mass remnant of 41.5% at 450 °C was consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (39.4% calc'd assuming loss of 2 equiv of water). Compound 3 showed a mass loss of 11.2% between ~65 °C and ~150 °C, matching exactly that predicted for removal of all aqua ligands and cocrystallized water molecules. Ligand combustion was evident from a rapid mass loss at ~270 °C. Its mass remnant of 38.3% at 450 °C is consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (35.7% calc'd) along with some uncombusted organics. Compound 4 exhibited a mass loss of 15.2% between 60 and 100 °C, matching well with the removal of all aqua ligands and cocrystallized water molecules (15.9% calc'd). Ligand ejection occurred above 270 °C. The final mass remnant of 35.8% is consistent with a likely deposition of CdCO3 (33.8% calc'd) and a small amount of uncombusted organics. Thermograms for 1-4 are shown in , respectively.

elements.content: A series of cadmium succinate coordination polymers has been prepared using all four possible isomers of a simple dipyridylamide as coligands. Common structural elements are linked together differently depending on the donor disposition and therefore the donor-to-donor distance within the dipyridylamide ligand. In the case of 4-pyridylisonicotinamide, the donor-to-donor distance is too long to directly pillar dimer-based cadmium succinate layers, resulting in a rather rare 6-connected self-penetrated network. The closer donor-to-donor distance in 3-pyridylnicotinamide allows a straight pillaring of similar cadmium succinate layers, forming the ubiquitous 6-connected primitive cubic topology. Slight adjustment of succinate binding mode resulted in cocrystallization of energetically similar supramolecular isomers in the latter case. Both the 4-pyridylnicotinamide and 3-pyridylisonicotinamide ligands have similar donor dispositions, and both afforded cadmium succinate helical chains in the resulting coordination polymers. The latter caused straight dipyridylamide connectivity and a simple 4-connected rectangular grid topology, while the former engaged in cross-pillaring and concomitant formation of an exceptionally rare self-penetrated layer topology. Some tuning of luminescence emission maxima is possible through varying the dipyridylamide component. In this series of coordination polymers, it does not appear that thermal robustness is enhanced by self-penetration. This work illustrates that employing four isomeric dipyridylamides as coligands across a specific divalent metal dicarboxylate system can result in significant coordination polymer topological diversity, in the process revealing supramolecular structure-direction trends.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of cadmium succinate coordination polymers has been prepared using all four possible isomers of a simple dipyridylamide as coligands. Common structural elements are linked together differently depending on the donor disposition and therefore the donor-to-donor distance within the dipyridylamide ligand. In the case of 4-pyridylisonicotinamide, the donor-to-donor distance is too long to directly pillar dimer-based cadmium succinate layers, resulting in a rather rare 6-connected self-penetrated network. The closer donor-to-donor distance in 3-pyridylnicotinamide allows a straight pillaring of similar cadmium succinate layers, forming the ubiquitous 6-connected primitive cubic topology. Slight adjustment of succinate binding mode resulted in cocrystallization of energetically similar supramolecular isomers in the latter case. Both the 4-pyridylnicotinamide and 3-pyridylisonicotinamide ligands have similar donor dispositions, and both afforded cadmium succinate helical chains in the resulting coordination polymers. The latter caused straight dipyridylamide connectivity and a simple 4-connected rectangular grid topology, while the former engaged in cross-pillaring and concomitant formation of an exceptionally rare self-penetrated layer topology. Some tuning of luminescence emission maxima is possible through varying the dipyridylamide component. In this series of coordination polymers, it does not appear that thermal robustness is enhanced by self-penetration. This work illustrates that employing four isomeric dipyridylamides as coligands across a specific divalent metal dicarboxylate system can result in significant coordination polymer topological diversity, in the process revealing supramolecular structure-direction trends.

Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (28 mg, 0.09 mmol) and succinic acid (14 mg, 0.11 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of H2O in a 15 mL glass vial. A 4 mL aliquot of a 1:1 ethanol/water solution was pipetted on top, followed by 3 mL of an ethanolic solution of 4-pina (18 mg, 0.09 mmol). The vial was allowed to stand uncapped for two weeks, whereupon colorless crystals were deposited.

The crystals of 1 (11 mg, 29% yield based on Cd) were isolated after washing with distilled water and acetone, and drying in air. Anal. Calcd. For C15H13CdN3O5: C 42.12, H 3.06, N 9.82%. Preparation of [Cd(suc)(4-pina)] n  (1)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (28 mg, 0.09 mmol) and succinic acid (14 mg, 0.11 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of H2O in a 15 mL glass vial. A 4 mL aliquot of a 1:1 ethanol/water solution was pipetted on top, followed by 3 mL of an ethanolic solution of 4-pina (18 mg, 0.09 mmol). The vial was allowed to stand uncapped for two weeks, whereupon colorless crystals were deposited.

The crystals of 1 (11 mg, 29% yield based on Cd) were isolated after washing with distilled water and acetone, and drying in air. Anal. Calcd. For C15H13CdN3O5: C 42.12, H 3.06, N 9.82%. Found: C 43.13, H 2.69, N 10.54%. IR (v, cm-1): 3282 (w, br), 1487 (m), 1594 (s), 1543 (s), 1520 (s), 1408 (s), 1330 (s), 1298 (s), 1345 (m), 1210 (s), 1118 (m), 1047 (m), 1014 (m), 937 (m), 899 (m), 831 (m), 755 (m).

Preparation of {[Cd(suc)(3-pna)]⋅2.5H2O} n  (2/2')

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (57 mg, 0.185 mmol), succinic acid (50 mg, 0.185 mmol), and 3-pna (37 mg, 0.185 mmol) were placed into 5 mL of distilled H2O in a 15 mL screw-cap vial, along with 1 mL of a 1.0 M NaOH solution. The vial was sealed and heated in an oil bath at 70 °C for 48 h and then cooled slowly to 25 °C. Colorless crystals of 2 and 2' (14 mg, 16% yield based on Cd) were isolated after washing with distilled water and acetone, and drying in air. Compound 2 crystallized as blocks, while compound 2' crystallized as needles. The different morphology allowed for distinction of the major product 2 and the minor product 2'. Bulk manual separation proved too difficult. Anal. Calc. for C60H72Cd4N12O30 4: C, 38.11; H, 3.84; N, 8.89% Found: C, 38.66; H, 3.42; N, 8.76%. cln_elements.content:
Adjacent [Cd(suc)(3-pina)(H2O)] n coordination polymer layers stack in an AAA pattern along the a crystal direction (), forming incipient channels occupying 19.1% of the unit cell volume, filled with cocrystallized water molecules. Trimers of fully occupied water molecules within these channels link through symmetry disordered water molecules to form discrete water molecule chains of varying lengths. These are anchored to the coordination polymer backbone by hydrogen-bonding donation to suc carboxylate oxygen atoms, and by hydrogen-bonding acceptance from the 3-pina amide moieties ().

Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on compounds 1–4 to investigate their degradation behavior. Compound 1 exhibited no mass loss until 185 °C, at which point ligand combustion occurred. Its mass remnant of 36.7% at 450 °C is roughly consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (40.1% calc’d). Compound 2/2′ likely partially dehydrated upon standing at room temperature upon storage for over a month, with a 2.0% mass loss between 40 and 80 °C indicative of removal of the remaining cocrystallized water molecules. The expected mass percent of cocrystallized water for the as-synthesized sample was 9.5%. Ligand ejection for 2/2′ occurred at ∼200 °C. The final mass remnant of 41.5% at 450 °C was consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (39.4% calc’d assuming loss of 2 equiv of water). Compound 3 showed a mass loss of 11.2% between ∼65 °C and ∼150 °C, matching exactly that predicted for removal of all aqua ligands and cocrystallized water molecules. Ligand combustion was evident from a rapid mass loss at ∼270 °C. Its mass remnant of 38.3% at 450 °C is consistent with a deposition of CdCO3 (35.7% calc’d) along with some uncombusted organics. Compound 4 exhibited a mass loss of 15.2% between 60 and 100 °C, matching well with the removal of all aqua ligands and cocrystallized water molecules (15.9% calc’d). Ligand ejection occurred above 270 °C. The final mass remnant of 35.8% is consistent with a likely deposition of CdCO3 (33.8% calc’d) and a small amount of uncombusted organics. Thermograms for 1–4 are shown in , respectively.
